Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: New Algorithims for Computing Equilibria of Stochastic Games

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research focuses on models of dynamic strategic behavior, in which two parties (individuals, nations, corporations, agencies) interact repeatedly over a long horizon and make decisions that have a persistent impact on the environment. The PIs are developing algorithms to simulate behavior in which each party has consistent beliefs about how others will behave and is maximizing their own welfare given those beliefs. These computational methods can be applied to a wide range of models that are used in various fields of economics, as well as in other disciplines such as international relations and evolutionary biology.

More specifically, the PIs study the pure strategy subgame perfect equilibria of infinitely repeated games with geometric discounting and a stochastic state variable. The state variable determines the set of actions that can be taken by the agents in each period of the game and the resultant payoffs. Conditional on the actions taken by the players, the state evolves as a Markov chain. The objective of the research is to develop algorithms for computing the discounted payoffs that players can obtain in subgame perfect equilibria starting in each state. The PIs will also develop and distribute software packages that implement the algorithms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded new research on computational methods in repeated games. Specifically, the project developed new algorithms for computing the pure-strategy subgame-perfect Nash equilibrium payoffs of stochastic games with perfect monitoring. The stochastic game is the standard model in economics and other disciplines for modeling strategic behavior when conditions vary over time. It has been used to help understand a variety of phenomena, such as dynamic oligopoly, political compromise, and risk sharing. Analytical characterizations of equilibrium payoffs have existed for a long time, but relatively little is known about how to efficiently compute equilibrium payoffs using numerical methods. We developed a new algorithm which can be used to exactly compute equilibrium payoffs. This algorithm is more efficient than previous methods. Moreover, when there are two players, our algorithm is of bounded computational complexity. We show by example that the problem of exactly computing equilibrium payoffs has unbounded computational complexity when there is more than two players. However, we adapt our method to compute approximate equilibrium payoffs. We also implemented our algorithm in C++, which is freely available from the authors under the terms of the GPLv3 license. This research is documented in the following peer-reviewed article:

Abreu, D., Brooks, B., & Sannikov, Y. (2020). Algorithms for Stochastic Games With Perfect Monitoring. Econometrica, 88(4), 1661-1695.
